questions.title: Monetary Policy
questions.question:
Given stable inflation, a tight fiscal policy accompanied by easy monetary policy will most likely:

  1. decrease the private sector share of GDP.
  2. have no impact on the private sector share of GDP.
  3. increase the private sector share of GDP.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. If tight fiscal policy is accompanied by easy monetary policy and low interest rates, the private sector share of GDP typically will increase (not decrease). Incorrect. If tight fiscal policy is accompanied by easy monetary policy and low interest rates, the private sector share of GDP typically will increase (not remain unchanged). An unchanged composition of aggregate demand, with the GDP shares attributable to the private and public sectors remaining stable, typically occurs in the context of parallel policy actions. That occurs with mutually reinforcing macroeconomic policies, either tight fiscal/tight monetary or easy fiscal/easy monetary. Correct. If tight fiscal policy is accompanied by easy monetary policy and low interest rates, the private sector will be stimulated and will increase as a share of GDP. Monetary Policy explain the interaction of monetary and fiscal policy
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. If tight fiscal policy is accompanied by easy monetary policy and low interest rates, the private sector share of GDP typically will increase (not decrease).

  2. Incorrect. If tight fiscal policy is accompanied by easy monetary policy and low interest rates, the private sector share of GDP typically will increase (not remain unchanged). An unchanged composition of aggregate demand, with the GDP shares attributable to the private and public sectors remaining stable, typically occurs in the context of parallel policy actions. That occurs with mutually reinforcing macroeconomic policies, either tight fiscal/tight monetary or easy fiscal/easy monetary.

  3. Correct. If tight fiscal policy is accompanied by easy monetary policy and low interest rates, the private sector will be stimulated and will increase as a share of GDP.

questions.title: Monetary Policy
questions.question:
Assuming wages and prices are rigid, which of the following policy combinations most likely leads to the private sector increasing its share of GDP?

  1. Easy fiscal policy and tight monetary policy
  2. Tight monetary policy and tight fiscal policy
  3. Tight fiscal policy and easy monetary policy
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because if taxes are cut or government spending rises, the expansionary fiscal policy will lead to a rise in aggregate output. If this is accompanied by a reduction in money supply to offset the fiscal expansion, then interest rates will rise and have a negative effect on private sector demand. We have higher output and higher interest rates, and government spending will be a larger proportion of overall national income. Incorrect because, in the case of tight monetary policy and tight fiscal policy, interest rates rise (at least if the monetary impact on interest rates is larger) and reduce private demand. At the same time, higher taxes and falling government spending lead to a drop in aggregate demand from both public and private sectors. Correct because if a fiscal contraction is accompanied by expansionary monetary policy and low interest rates, then the private sector will be stimulated and will rise as a share of GDP, while the public sector will shrink. Monetary Policy explain the interaction of monetary and fiscal policy
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because if taxes are cut or government spending rises, the expansionary fiscal policy will lead to a rise in aggregate output. If this is accompanied by a reduction in money supply to offset the fiscal expansion, then interest rates will rise and have a negative effect on private sector demand. We have higher output and higher interest rates, and government spending will be a larger proportion of overall national income.

  2. Incorrect because, in the case of tight monetary policy and tight fiscal policy, interest rates rise (at least if the monetary impact on interest rates is larger) and reduce private demand. At the same time, higher taxes and falling government spending lead to a drop in aggregate demand from both public and private sectors.

  3. Correct because if a fiscal contraction is accompanied by expansionary monetary policy and low interest rates, then the private sector will be stimulated and will rise as a share of GDP, while the public sector will shrink.

Monetary Policy

  • explain the interaction of monetary and fiscal policy

questions.title: Monetary Policy
questions.question:
As a monetary policy tool, quantitative easing (QE) will most likely help revive an ailing economy in which of the following environments?

  1. Deflationary trap
  2. Declining bank reserves and economic activity
  3. Liquidity trap
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. Deflation is a pervasive and persistent fall in a general price index and is more difficult for conventional monetary policy to deal with than inflation. This is because once the monetary authority has cut nominal interest rates to zero to stimulate the economy, it cannot cut them any further. It is at this point that the economic conditions for a liquidity trap arise. Deflation raises the real value of debt, while the persistent fall in prices can encourage consumers to put off current consumption, leading to a fall in demand that leads to further deflationary pressure. Thus a deflationary “trap” can develop, which is characterized by weak consumption growth, falling prices, and increases in real debt levels. Correct. Quantitative easing (QE) is an “unconventional” approach to monetary policy and is operationally similar to open market purchase operations but conducted on a much larger scale. The additional reserves created by central banks in a policy of quantitative easing can be used to buy any assets. The idea is that this additional reserve will kick-start lending, causing broad money growth to expand, which will eventually lead to an increase in real economic activity. Incorrect. A liquidity trap is associated with occasions where the demand for money becomes infinitely elastic—that is, where the demand curve is horizontal and individuals are willing to hold additional money balances without any change in the interest rate—so that further injections of money into the economy will not serve to further lower interest rates or affect real activity. In this extreme circumstance, monetary policy can become completely ineffective. Monetary Policy describe qualities of effective central banks; contrast their use of inflation, interest rate, and exchange rate targeting in expansionary or contractionary monetary policy; and describe the limitations of monetary policy
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. Deflation is a pervasive and persistent fall in a general price index and is more difficult for conventional monetary policy to deal with than inflation. This is because once the monetary authority has cut nominal interest rates to zero to stimulate the economy, it cannot cut them any further. It is at this point that the economic conditions for a liquidity trap arise. Deflation raises the real value of debt, while the persistent fall in prices can encourage consumers to put off current consumption, leading to a fall in demand that leads to further deflationary pressure. Thus a deflationary “trap” can develop, which is characterized by weak consumption growth, falling prices, and increases in real debt levels.

  2. Correct. Quantitative easing (QE) is an “unconventional” approach to monetary policy and is operationally similar to open market purchase operations but conducted on a much larger scale. The additional reserves created by central banks in a policy of quantitative easing can be used to buy any assets. The idea is that this additional reserve will kick-start lending, causing broad money growth to expand, which will eventually lead to an increase in real economic activity.

  3. Incorrect. A liquidity trap is associated with occasions where the demand for money becomes infinitely elastic—that is, where the demand curve is horizontal and individuals are willing to hold additional money balances without any change in the interest rate—so that further injections of money into the economy will not serve to further lower interest rates or affect real activity. In this extreme circumstance, monetary policy can become completely ineffective.

  • describe qualities of effective central banks; contrast their use of inflation, interest rate, and exchange rate targeting in expansionary or contractionary monetary policy; and describe the limitations of monetary policy

To protect the exchange rate target, the developing country’s monetary authority will purchase foreign exchange reserves and sell its own currency. This will increase the domestic money supply, decrease short-term interest rates, and increase foreign exchange reserves. questions.title: Monetary Policy
questions.question:
If there is a policy rate of 3%, a real trend rate of growth in the underlying economy of 1%, and long-run expected inflation of 3%, then the central bank policy stance operating within a credible inflation-targeting regime is best described as:

  1. contractionary.
  2. neutral.
  3. expansionary.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because, with a contractionary policy stance, the central bank’s policy rate would be greater than the neutral rate. In this case, the policy rate of 3% is less than the neutral rate of 4% (1% trend growth plus 3% long-run inflation expectation), which is expansionary (not contractionary). Incorrect because, with a neutral policy stance, the central bank’s policy rate would be equal to the neutral rate. In this case, the policy rate of 3% is less than the neutral rate of 4% (1% trend growth plus 3% long-run inflation expectation), which is expansionary (not neutral). Correct. A real trend rate of growth of 1%, coupled with 3% long-run expected inflation, suggests a 4% neutral rate of interest that neither spurs on nor slows down the underlying economy. The 3% policy rate is less than the 4% neutral rate of interest. When the policy rate is below the neutral rate, monetary policy is described as expansionary. Monetary Policy describe qualities of effective central banks; contrast their use of inflation, interest rate, and exchange rate targeting in expansionary or contractionary monetary policy; and describe the limitations of monetary policy
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because, with a contractionary policy stance, the central bank’s policy rate would be greater than the neutral rate. In this case, the policy rate of 3% is less than the neutral rate of 4% (1% trend growth plus 3% long-run inflation expectation), which is expansionary (not contractionary).

  2. Incorrect because, with a neutral policy stance, the central bank’s policy rate would be equal to the neutral rate. In this case, the policy rate of 3% is less than the neutral rate of 4% (1% trend growth plus 3% long-run inflation expectation), which is expansionary (not neutral).

  3. Correct. A real trend rate of growth of 1%, coupled with 3% long-run expected inflation, suggests a 4% neutral rate of interest that neither spurs on nor slows down the underlying economy. The 3% policy rate is less than the 4% neutral rate of interest. When the policy rate is below the neutral rate, monetary policy is described as expansionary.

questions.question:
In an effort to influence the economy, a central bank conducted open market activities by selling government bonds. This action implies that the central bank is most likely attempting to:

  1. contract the economy by reducing bank reserves.
  2. contract the economy through a lower policy interest rate.
  3. expand the economy through a lower policy interest rate.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. Selling government bonds results in a reduction of bank reserves and reduces their ability to lend, causing a decline in money growth through the multiplier mechanism and hence a contraction in the economy. Incorrect. Central bank selling of bonds will reduce the money supply through its impact on bank reserves, which will result in a higher, not lower, interest rate. Incorrect. Central bank selling of bonds is not expansionary. Monetary Policy describe tools used to implement monetary policy tools and the monetary transmission mechanism, and explain the relationships between monetary policy and economic growth, inflation, interest, and exchange rates
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. Selling government bonds results in a reduction of bank reserves and reduces their ability to lend, causing a decline in money growth through the multiplier mechanism and hence a contraction in the economy.

  2. Incorrect. Central bank selling of bonds will reduce the money supply through its impact on bank reserves, which will result in a higher, not lower, interest rate.

  3. Incorrect. Central bank selling of bonds is not expansionary.

questions.title: Monetary Policy
questions.question:
Which of the following actions on the part of a central bank is most consistent with increasing the quantity of money?

  1. Increasing reserve requirements
  2. Increasing the central bank policy rate
  3. Purchasing securities on the open market
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. If the central bank increases required reserve ratios, the banks will decrease lending and the money supply will decline. Incorrect. The higher the policy rate, the higher the potential penalty that banks will have to pay to the central bank if they run short of liquidity, the greater will be their willingness to reduce lending, and the more likely the money supply will decrease. Correct. When a central bank purchases securities, bank reserves increase. The banks therefore have excess reserves and are able to increase their lending, increasing the money supply. Solution

  2. Incorrect. The higher the policy rate, the higher the potential penalty that banks will have to pay to the central bank if they run short of liquidity, the greater will be their willingness to reduce lending, and the more likely the money supply will decrease.

questions.title: Monetary Policy
questions.question:
The transmission of a central bank’s policy rate action through the economy ultimately affects:

  1. inflation.
  2. total demand.
  3. long-term interest rates.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. The monetary transmission mechanism is the process whereby a central bank’s interest rate gets transmitted through the economy and ultimately affects the rate of increase of prices (inflation). Incorrect because, although policy rate actions do transmit through the economy by affecting total demand, this influence on total demand is an intermediate effect that drives subsequent domestic inflationary pressure. In effect, policy rate actions ultimately impact inflation through the avenue of total demand. Incorrect because although policy rate actions do transmit through the economy through the channel of market rates (both short-term and long-term interest rates), this is just one of four channels and multiple interconnected channel relationships that impacts total demand. In effect, policy rate actions ultimately impact inflation through the channel of market interest rates (including long-term interest rates). Monetary Policy describe tools used to implement monetary policy tools and the monetary transmission mechanism, and explain the relationships between monetary policy and economic growth, inflation, interest, and exchange rates
